data.title: Filmmakers & Organizations Working Together to Expose Human Rights Abuses
data.meta_description: Production, Outreach and Legal Support for Award-Winning Film No Fire Zone
data.text:
Bertha Foundation supports activists, storytellers and lawyers working to bring about human rights for all. We believe that social change can happen effectively when these groups and individuals come together to work on a common issue. The storytelling portfolio works to nurture global talent, expose relevant stories and connect them to audiences for powerful, positive social change.

In 2012, the Bertha team was introduced to journalist and director Callum Macrae, who was working on a film to expose human rights abuses in Sri Lanka. As a result, over a period of three years, Bertha provided production, outreach and distribution support to the multi-award winning documentary No Fire Zone. In order to further amplify the film’s social impact, Bertha Foundation also connected the film team with grantees in Bertha’s legal and activism portfolios.

No Fire Zone Film Overview

Using firsthand testimony and video evidence, No Fire Zone tells the narrative of the last 138 days of the 26-year Sri Lankan Civil War. In January 2009, the government of Sri Lanka launched its final offensive against the secessionist rebels, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, better known as the Tamil Tigers. Two weeks into the final assault, the government declared the first “No Fire Zone” and encouraged between 300,000 and 400,000 Tamil civilians to gather there, for their own safety. The government then launched a deadly, sustained and deliberate shelling campaign on this and subsequent zones. The story of what happened next is told in detail by the film’s central characters.

The documentary had an accompanying outreach campaign with an emphasis on bringing worldwide attention to the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Sri Lanka, and on convincing the UN Human Rights Council to vote for an independent international inquiry into the war crimes committed at the end of the conflict.

Click here to see a short presentation outlining the historical context of the film.

Production Support

"We quickly recognized the importance this film could have on the international stage and reacted with a Bertha Film Fund grant so the team could finish their film and have it ready for key policymaker screenings. Their hard work paid off."

Rebecca Lichtenfeld,

Director, Social Impact Media, Bertha Foundation

Bertha provided funding to No Fire Zone through the Bertha Film Fund so that the film team could finish editing in time for critical screenings in India and Switzerland. The Bertha Film Fund offers grants for the creation of social impact documentary content at various stages. By being able to support a project during different points in the film’s trajectory, Bertha was able to fund swiftly, enabling the team to cross the finish line right when it was needed most.

With the Commonwealth (former British colonies) Heads of Government Meeting taking place at the end of 2013 in Sri Lanka and the Sri Lankan government due to report to the UN Human Rights Council in March of 2014 regarding their plans to address the allegations of war crimes, the film team knew they needed a high quality version of the documentary ready to screen to officials to encourage them to hold Sri Lanka’s government to account. The 2013 Commonwealth summit in Sri Lanka was supposed to mark the country’s return to the international diplomatic fold after the successful closing out of the civil war. Bertha provided funds to the filmmakers so that they could release their film in advance of these crucial moments while the world had its eyes on Sri Lanka.

In addition to these influencer screenings, the film also screened across the world, including at festivals like Sheffield Doc/Fest and the Movies that Matter Film Festival. The feature-length documentary was nominated for an International Emmy Award and Sri Lanka’s Killing Fields, the accompanying TV series special, won a Peabody Award and was nominated for a BAFTA.

Outreach Support

"Bertha’s commitment to supporting and facilitating our outreach and impact work in the Global South - particularly in Asia - was absolutely vital in reaching audiences who could identify with the victims of war crimes, torture and state-sponsored disappearances. Our impact in India in particular was due, in great measure, to Bertha’s support."

Callum Macrae,

Director, No Fire Zone

The Sri Lankan government was not being held to account by the international community for war crimes committed during the war. Tamil repression continued. In an effort to get the international community to support a potential UN Human Rights Council resolution on Sri Lanka and accountability, the film team organized policymaker screenings in key countries. The film team wanted to strengthen the resolve of supportive member states of the Human Rights Council, sway undecided member states and educate and persuade new member states to take a strong stance.

Campaign Objectives

Via a grant from the Bertha Doc Society Connect Fund, the film team went to India to lobby for the country’s support. India’s vote as part of the UN Human Rights Council was judged to be especially influential, particularly to nations in the Global South, due to its proximity to Sri Lanka and status in the Commonwealth. Active 2012-2017, the Bertha Doc Society Connect Fund was an outreach and engagement fund available to filmmakers around the world and awarded to film teams with smart, strategic campaigns which had the ability to achieve real change on a local, regional or global level. This fund has now been brought in-house at Bertha Foundation.

In February 2013, a month before the film’s premiere at the UN Palais des Nations in Geneva, the team released extracts from the film to key politicians and opinion formers in India and launched a major multimedia campaign to mobilize support. The team targeted the most influential outlets across different print and TV media, both locally and internationally. They also met with 12 Indian Members of Parliament in their lobbying efforts.

The Indian board of film certification refused to release the film theatrically to prevent “strain[ing] friendly relations with Sri Lanka.” Following this and other attempts to ban the film in Sri Lanka, Malaysia and Nepal, the film team made the documentary available as a free download in English, Sinhala and Hindi so that wide audiences could still have access to the film.

Campaign Outcomes

In total, over 150 articles were written worldwide

International politicians made public statements, including the then UK Prime Minister, Leader of the Opposition and Deputy Prime Minister

Indian daily newspaper The Hindu published a front-page article by Director Callum Macrae about the human rights abuses that occurred in Sri Lanka, in particular the killing of Balachandran, the 12-year-old son of one of the leaders of the Tamil Tigers

Director Callum Macrae was refused a visa to India, a move by India’s government that was condemned in an editorial in the Times of India and by the main opposition party

The main opposition party in Tamil Nadu withdrew from the Indian governing coalition in protest as a result of the Balachandran revelation

The film ignited mass student protests, including a hunger strike, as well as parliamentary debates in India

The Indian government supported the resolution on Sri Lanka’s accountability when it was voted on at the UN Human Rights Council in March 2013

Then Prime Minister of India, Manmohan Singh, boycotted the Commonwealth summit over the Sri Lankan human rights abuses

Bertha DocHouse

Bertha DocHouse, the UK’s first documentary film center, hosted a preview screening of No Fire Zone that brought together politicians, filmmakers and advocates and was hosted by Channel 4’s Jon Snow.

Screening the Film for Activists

in Brazil

In April 2015, the film also screened for Bertha activism grantees at the Political Training for Political Educators Course in English which took place at the Escola Nacional Florestan Fernandes founded by Movimento dos Trabalhadores Rurais Sem Terra (MST) in Brazil.

Legal Support

"Supporting the No Fire Zone team to conceive of and execute a legal strategy to pursue alongside the film’s release was essential. Since the film included new evidence of human rights abuses committed at the end of the Sri Lankan civil war, there were many ways the footage could be used to support a parallel legal campaign for justice for victims. We connected them with lawyers documenting the crimes for submission to the UN to cross-verify evidence. For any film-related legal advocacy, it was crucial that the film covered the legal issues with accuracy and credibility - and No Fire Zone did just that."

Jennifer Robinson,

Former Director, Bertha Justice Initiative, Bertha Foundation

The then Director of the Bertha Justice Initiative helped the film team structure and articulate their legal advocacy goals and strategies, including how best to reach out to members of the Commonwealth prior to the summit in Sri Lanka. Bertha gave a simultaneous grant to the International Crimes Evidence Project (ICEP), housed at the Public Interest Advocacy Centre (PIAC) in Australia, to investigate allegations of Sri Lankan war crimes.

Created to provide independent and impartial evidence gathering and analysis, ICEP was invited to submit its findings to the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights to inform its investigation. The evidence collected was also used to garner U.S. and international support for Human Rights Council action on Sri Lanka

Through use of the Media Impact Opportunity Fund, a Bertha fund designed to respond to time-sensitive inter-network opportunities, we provided a grant to support Lena Hendry, “the first human rights activist charged in Malaysia for screening a film.” At the Freedom Film Festival in 2013, Lena was charged by the Malaysian government for screening No Fire Zone, a film that was not vetted and approved by the Film Censorship Board of Malaysia.

Additionally, Bertha and Doc Society teamed up to pen an open letter in support of her release which garnered signatures from nearly 100 high-profile filmmakers, artists and influencers, demanding that the charges be dropped.

With the help of Bertha and Doc Society, Hendry participated in the 2016 Impact Producer Lab in Helsinki, where impact producers from around the world gathered to build camaraderie and discuss strategies. Hendry then attended Doc Society’s 2017 Global Impact Producer Assembly, also funded by a Media Impact Opportunity Grant, where she spoke about how to fight for freedom of speech and expression in a state with strict censorship laws.

Outcomes

"Without Bertha’s support - and that of our other partners - I do think the world would remain far more ignorant of the terrible crimes committed against innocent Tamil civilians by their own government and the struggle for justice would have been set back significantly.”

Callum Macrae,

Director, No Fire Zone

With help from survivors, organizations and critics of the Sri Lankan government, the No Fire Zone film team played a crucial role in achieving their primary aim of launching an independent international inquiry. This was a first step towards making the Sri Lankan government accountable internationally for war crimes

Four public statements were made from the then UK Prime Minister David Cameron, Leader of the Opposition and Deputy Prime Minister. After watching the documentary, Cameron tweeted that: “This documentary raises very serious questions that the Sri Lankan government must answer about what it did to protect innocent civilians. Questions that strengthen the case for an independent investigation.” He would raise these questions with then Sri Lankan President Mahinda Rajapaksa when he arrived in Colombo for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting

No Fire Zone was cited by Navi Pillay, Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) in a report to Human Rights Council in September 2013 and in the UN resolution in March 2014 to set up an international inquiry

David Cameron visited the Tamil homelands; this was the first visit by a foreign leader since Sri Lanka’s independence in 1948

A major and well-financed campaign was launched against the film team by Sri Lankan government supporters, including a 222 page book critiquing the film. Director Callum Macrae responded by writing a detailed 20,000 word rebuttal, which Norwegian Foreign minister Erik Solheim called “the most impressive rebuttal I have ever read”

The film was translated into the Sinhala language to allow the majority Sinhala population to see for the first time the shocking evidence of war crimes and massacres committed by their own government's force

Sri Lankan former Foreign Minister Mangala Samaraweera confirmed the authenticity of Channel 4 video footage documenting war crimes in an open letter to former President Mahinda Rajapaksa - click here to read the open letter

On 22 March 2017, Lena Hendry was sentenced to pay a fine of RM 10,000 (about €2,100) or spend a year in jail by the Magistrates’ Court in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, for screening No Fire Zone. The prosecution appealed the decision for a higher sentence, and on 14 December 2017, the High Court struck down the appeal

A group of organizations and individuals representing victims from the North and Eastern parts of Sri Lanka handed over a letter to then UN Secretary General, Ban Ki-moon regarding the country’s disregard for victims and failure to pursue charges of war crimes
